pull.title: Add ChaCha20 encryption option (XOR)
pull.body:
The current ChaCha20 implementation does not support message encryption (it can only output the keystream which is sufficient for the RNG).

This PR adds the actual XORing of the `plaintext` with the `keystream` in order to return the desired `ciphertext`.

Required for v2 message transport protocol.

issue.title: Add chacha20/poly1305 and chacha20poly1305_AEAD from openssh
issue.body:
This adds **ChaCha20** and **Poly1305** and the openSSH form of the AEAD.

The implementations of **ChaCha20** are from DJB himself and directly taken (unchanged as much as possible) from the openSSH source code: https://github.com/openssh/openssh-portable/blob/master/chacha.c

**Poly1305** is written by Andrew Moon is also directly taken (unchanged as much as possible) from the openSSH source code: https://github.com/openssh/openssh-portable/blob/master/poly1305.c

The code for the **ChaCha20/Poly1305@openssh** AEAD is taken from https://github.com/openssh/openssh-portable/blob/master/cipher-chachapoly.c with minimal changes.

More details on the AEAD construction:
https://github.com/openssh/openssh-portable/blob/master/PROTOCOL.chacha20poly1305
https://gist.github.com/jonasschnelli/c530ea8421b8d0e80c51486325587c52

Test vectors are taken from the RFC draft:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-agl-tls-chacha20poly1305-04#section-7

Taking existing implementations should reduce risks of screwing up at the implementation level.

**OUT OF SCOPE**:
* AVX,SSE acceleration (possible, see libsodium a.s.o.)
* To Bitcoin Core adjusted C++ implementations
* Combining with the existing ChaCha20 RNG
 (can all be done later, after verification of the correctness)

This is a subset of #14032 and a pre-requirement for BIP151.

issue.title: Add Poly1305 implementation
issue.body:
This adds a currently unused Poly1305 implementation including test vectors from RFC7539.

Required for BIP151 (and related to #15512).

issue.title: Add ChaCha20Poly1305@Bitcoin AEAD
issue.body:
This adds a new AEAD (authenticated encryption with additional data) construct optimised for small messages (like used in Bitcoins p2p network).

Includes: #15519, #15512 (please review those first).

The construct is specified here.
https://gist.github.com/jonasschnelli/c530ea8421b8d0e80c51486325587c52#ChaCha20Poly1305Bitcoin_Cipher_Suite

This aims for being used in v2 peer-to-peer messages.

events.body: utACK 427b49dcdbfb25153ee4228dda49aa07db16d59c. Changes since last review: splitting Output/Crypt functions, dropping comment describing function arguments, adding comment describing m/tmp copy, dropping XOR macro, and making suggested test changes.

Implementation and tests look good and match the reference implementation here: https://cr.yp.to/streamciphers/timings/estreambench/submissions/salsa20/chacha8/merged/chacha.c and test vector here: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7539#section-2.4.2

I have a few minor comments inline, and would be curious about the answer to:
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15512#discussion_r280833386

Looks great. Thanks for adding the comments to chacha20.h!

Just a couple of nits in the bench file. I'm still curious about the code duplication between `Keystream()` and `Crypt()`.

verification.payload:
tree 13031d138821514c1417e178c717ef73ccc49d6a
parent 2bc2b8b49ad87376d98591b14403dc3b46e3166b
author Jonas Schnelli <dev@jonasschnelli.ch> 1551779450 +0100

Add ChaCha20 bench

events.body:
Looks good. utACK 2dfe2751713c814aea53b5a7563eb74ad1baea00.

In general, it's better to have less code duplication, so I'd like to hear from @sipa his reasoning for https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15512#discussion_r269692281

@jnewbery I just thought that it'd be preferable not to burden the RNG code with branches that are only used for encryption. In cryptographic code like this, I don't care too much about duplication, as it isn't code that subject to many possible future changes.

ok, my aesthetic preference is for less duplication, either by having a single Keystream/Crypt function, or by calling Keystream() from Crypt() with a zero'ed message. As sipa points out though, this code is unlikely to be modified much in future, so it's not a big deal either way.

utACK 2dfe2751713c814aea53b5a7563eb74ad1baea00

utACK 2dfe2751713c814aea53b5a7563eb74ad1baea00. Changes since last review are just renaming the Crypt method, adding comments, and simplifying the benchmark.

> I just thought that it'd be preferable not to burden the RNG code with branches that are only used for encryption.

I think the duplication is fine, but it's unclear if the concern with branches is about readability or performance. If it's performance, you could give the previous `Output()` function an additional `template<bool use_input>` template argument, and have `Crypt()` and `Keystream()` both call it inlined.

issue.title: Backport chacha-poly1305, prepare for V2 P2P Encrypted Messaging
issue.body:
This backports #15512 #15519 and #15649. This prepares us to be able to backport the v2 encrypted messaging system once the implementation is finalized in bitcoin. We could also not merge this until bitcoin is done implementing v2 messaging system, but since I would want a lot of manual testing on the v2 messaging system (and it might have a lot of merge conflicts) I think it makes sense to do this as a seperate backporting PR. 

The PR to implement the V2 messaging system will likely end up being https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14032

issue.title: [Refactor] Update RNG code from upstream
issue.body:
This is a collection of upstream PRs that have been backported to bring our RNG (`src/random`) code more up-to-date. The following upstream PRs have been included here:

- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/12742
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14624 
  - some of this had already been merged previously
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14955
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15250
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15224
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15324
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15296
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15512
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/16878
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17151
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17191
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13236
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13314
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17169
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17270
  -  omitted last commit as our testing framework doesn't support it currently
  - omitted https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17270/commits/64e1e022cedf6776c5dffd488ca2e766adca5dc3, to be pulled in after our time utility is updated in a separate PR
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17573
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17507
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17670
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17527
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14127
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/21486

comments.body: A comment would be helpful here: "If m has fewer than 64 bytes available, copy m to tmp and read from tmp instead"
Just `memcpy(tmp, m, bytes)` might be simpler and easy to read than this for loop.
Not sure what the benefit of defining XOR macro is. Isn't `x0 ^= ReadLE32(m + 0)` more readable and less error-prone than `x0 = XOR(x0, ReadLE32(m + 0))`?

This comment seems imply that output is not written if input is null. Maybe rephrase: "If \<input> is non-null, the specified number of \<bytes> from \<input> will encrypted and written to \<output>, otherwise just the keystream will be written to \<output\> (which may be useful for random number generation). Either way, the number of bytes written to \<output> will be \<bytes>."
Maybe `assert(hex_message.empty() || m.size() == out.size())`
It seems like a useful additional test would be call `rng.Output` twice if `hex_message` is nonempty, once with input and once without, and confirm that xoring the two outputs yields the input again.

I'm not to familiar with compiler optimisations and stuff but I just checked the reference implementation by DJB and some other C based ChaCha implementations and all of them seems to use the byte per byte assignment. I prefer to leave it as it is.
Good point. Added.
Added.
Valid point. Fixed.
Added.
Thanks for the review! Your right. Changed.

I think it would be better to duplicate the logic here and turn the stream cipher version into a separate function.

As is, it introduces an unnecessary branch in the output version.
Good point. Adapted the duplication approach.
No need for this `if`.
Yes. Fixed.
nit: why the extra newline?

Now that this class can encrypt plaintext, the class comment should be updated from "A PRNG class for ChaCha20."

Really, I'd like to see more commenting for this class in general (ie note that `SetIV` sets the nonce, `Seek` sets the counter, that the counter is 64 bytes and the nonce is 64 bytes as in the original ChaCha20 spec instead of 32 byte counter/96 byte nonce as in the IETF spec).

(there are a couple of good resources on the different counter/nonce sizes here: https://libsodium.gitbook.io/doc/advanced/stream_ciphers/chacha20 and here: http://loup-vaillant.fr/tutorials/chacha20-design)
nit: This function should be renamed `Keystream` now that the class is not just used for PRNG
This test seems redundant to me. How could it ever fail if the test above succeeds?

re: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15512#discussion_r280836767

Not sure exactly what you want to get rid of, but if you're talking about the `out == outres` check below, I suggested it and think it'd be better to keep, because it means if the test passes you can be reassured that Crypt() and Output() results are consistent without manually verifying `4c616 ^ 6e2e3 == 224f5`... in the test cases.
Renamed to `Keystream`

The IETF has a slightly modified recommendation AFAIK.
We use Bernstein-Vanilly 64bit nonce and 64bit block counter.

* Changed the class comment
* Added some function comments
micronit: same line or braces for while code block please! Same for while block in `HASH()` below.
Is a reason you've added these `CHash256` benchmarks to chacha20.cpp?

I added if for comparison and the impact on the networking... though I think it belong to an extra commit in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15649
Will remove it from here.

I had it in the initial version like @jnewbery just proposed.
After @sipa recommended to separate it, I thought that a strict separation may be beneficial for verification and later optimizations. But maybe @sipa can clarify...
Fixed
Isn't this no-op? When `bytes < 64` line 215 get's executed which makes ctarget and c equal pointers, therefore it's copying a value to itself.
I like the renaming. Would be nice if the comments included information about pointers (e.g. "key must be non-null, pointer isn't stored").

I don't think so.
If we do less then 64 bytes, we execute the round on `tmp` (because we do 64bytes always, see line 216, `c` points to `tmp` if <64 bytes). So in the case of <64 bytes, `c` points to the temporary 64byte buffer and `ctarget` points to the function provided `c` argument.
Yes. That would have been useful. Feel free to PR.
Ah, yes, missed that. Thanks and sorry for bothering.
